section.title: mda Leslie
section.para: A port of mda's Leslie Rotary Speaker simulator.

A Leslie speaker is a special amplifier and set of speakers mounted in such a way that the rotation of the components creates a pleasing doppler effect. It's something like a very wide chorus and phaser. There is a crossover circuit so the exact parameters of the sound can be controlled independently for high and low tones.
This sound is especially suited to electric pianos and (Hammond) organs.

entry.para: Overall operation speed. Can be one of 'STOP' (no rotation), 'SLOW' or 'FAST'. Param 'Finespeed' futher allows you to tweak actual speed to suit.
Output gain. Use to give signal a boost if operation attenuates signal a little.
Crossover frequency between hi and low speakers. Moving this up can result in a more disorientating sound.
High tone speaker (tweeter) stereo modulation width. Makes the sound wobble from side to side more!
High tone speaker phase shift size. Sort of simulates the sound receding and approaching.
As for high width, but for low tones from the woofer.
Fine control over rotation speed. Can take a few seconds to reach the desired speed, to simulate the momentum of a real Leslie speaker!
Again, as for high throb but for low tones.
